DR. HERMAN OLIPHANT

FORMER HOPKINS
PROFESSOR HONORED

At Levering Hall

Emphasizing the fact that sociological and economic interests play
a much more important part in separating groups today than does rereligion, Dr. Ivan E. McDoygle,
head of the Department of Social
Sciences at Goucher College, addressed a discussion group in Levering Hall last Wednesday.
Dr. McDoygle, talking on group
solidarity, pointed out that many
conflicts have arisen in the last century or two because people are coming in closer contact with each other,
and the old geographical separations

it is in the case of our 14-7 loss to Lehigh. But the
Penn State and U. of M. encounters are in a far
different category.
Our sports-columnist summarized the situation
very neatly last Tuesday in discussing the relative
sources of material for the teams. Hopkins depending upon the local talent, and the other schools importing players. But the reason for keeping these
superior teams on our schedule may be more than a
mere matter of tradition. We have burdensome presentiments that the financial aspect charms the minds
in the athletic office.
True enough, no team can survive without adequate financial backing—at least of some sort. But
does that necessitate the subjecting of our light-weight
and insufficiently-trained players to all sorts of physical beatings by stronger teams? After nearly every
game which has .been in any degree hotly contested
the players have come out very much battered up,
more so than usual or necessary. The responsibility
for winning the game rests upon two or three star
players whom the coach dare not remove from play,
and they are in constant danger of grave physical injury. Don Kelly may not play any basketball this
year because of his wrenched back; Pete Reynolds is
definitely out of further athletic activity; Bill McClean is in none too good a state.
Some of this injury is due to the poor equipment
used. The pants and helmets are notoriously deficient in padding and have not been replaced for a
long time. A little of the profits made on these "big
games" might be invested to good advantage in protecting the life and limb of the team. But that is not
the salient fault; the trouble is that these heavier
, teams should appear on our schedule at all. Athletics
after all are meant for enjoyment and constructiveness in health for the participants, and not to turn out
winning machines. According to the present arrangements the team does not prepare for the next game;
it merely tries to recover from the last one in time
for its next punishment. It's a sort of a glorified
gladiatorial circus.
If we can ever separate the athletic department
from the emphasis which it places upon the financial
end of the work we will have achieved the most notable advance which has been made in sports at the
Hopkins in years. The primary consideration, we
insist, is not the gate but the assurance that when
the game is over there will be eleven men who are
fairly sound. in body and not the victims of some
complicated injuries which may cripple them for life.
It's not worth the price.

J. H. U. Man Invents Totalisator
For Automatic Horse Betting

At The
Playshop

Henry Straus, Hopkins Graduate And Former Instructor, Two more 'performances of Oef4
Finds His Electrical Device A Great Success
"Blind Man's Buff", "Fatti Mas
schi Parole Femine", and of
At Pimlico Track
One more Johns Hopkins man
has attracted widespread praise in
the world and has climbed the ladder of success. This man is Mr.
Henry Lobe Straus, and his most
notable achievement is his invention
of the totalisator, an electrically controlled, automatic, betting device
which recently made its Eastern debut in America at the Pimlico racetrack.
Mr. Straus, a native of Baltimore,
received his Bachelor of Science degree in the School of Engineering
here in 1917, after having graduated from Baltimore City College.
In the scholastic year 1919-20 he
also was an instructor in mechanical
engineering at the Hopkins, and he
is now a successful consulting engineer here in Baltimore.

utilized. The universal approval it
received there led to its introduction
to America, and it got its first
chance at Arlington Park, Chicago,
last summer. Its success there was
instantaneous, and it just recently
was installed at Pimlico. That it
met with the highest approval there
of all concerned is shown by the
fact that Mr. Straus has received a
contract to install his invention at
the Tanforan track in California,
and the machine is now in use at
Hialeah Park in Florida. The universal success of the device is assured, and Mr. Straus is soon to
leave for the West Coast with his
crew of mechanics to install it at
other tracks.

We quote from the Baltimore Evening Sun:

Don Kelly, injured quarterback, showed a real spirit. Before
the game and during the first
half he sat in his street clothes
on the Jay bench. His back was
sore and has been for some time.
He wasn't fit to play football. But
when the teams went to the
dressing rooms at the half, Kelly
also went in. He donned a uniform and asked his coach if he
might play. "I feel fine," he said,
and who could dispute his word.
So Don went in the game, but
his advent didn't help the situation.

The most important problem of
China today is the preservation of
its historic culture, said Father Edward Brennan in an address to the
members of the Charles Carroll
Club at a meeting in Levering Hall,
Sunday.
In his address, Father Brennan asserted that China, whose cultural
antiquity rivals that of the Occidental civilizations, is now at a crisis
in her historical development, as the
great Chinese culture is strongly
threatened by the attitude of the
young people of the nation.

it is in the case of our 14-7 loss to Lehigh. But the
Penn State and U. of M. encounters are in a far
different category.
Our sports-columnist summarized the situation
very neatly last Tuesday in discussing the relative
sources of material for the teams. Hopkins depending upon the local talent, and the other schools importing players. But the reason for keeping these
superior teams on our schedule may be more than a
mere matter of tradition. We have burdensome presentiments that the financial aspect charms the minds
in the athletic office.
True enough, no team can survive without adequate financial backing—at least of some sort. But
does that necessitate the subjecting of our light-weight
and insufficiently-trained players to all sorts of physical beatings by stronger teams? After nearly every
game which has .been in any degree hotly contested
the players have come out very much battered up,
more so than usual or necessary. The responsibility
for winning the game rests upon two or three star
players whom the coach dare not remove from play,
and they are in constant danger of grave physical injury. Don Kelly may not play any basketball this
year because of his wrenched back; Pete Reynolds is
definitely out of further athletic activity; Bill McClean is in none too good a state.
Some of this injury is due to the poor equipment
used. The pants and helmets are notoriously deficient in padding and have not been replaced for a
long time. A little of the profits made on these "big
games" might be invested to good advantage in protecting the life and limb of the team. But that is not
the salient fault; the trouble is that these heavier
, teams should appear on our schedule at all. Athletics
after all are meant for enjoyment and constructiveness in health for the participants, and not to turn out
winning machines. According to the present arrangements the team does not prepare for the next game;
it merely tries to recover from the last one in time
for its next punishment. It's a sort of a glorified
gladiatorial circus.
If we can ever separate the athletic department
from the emphasis which it places upon the financial
end of the work we will have achieved the most notable advance which has been made in sports at the
Hopkins in years. The primary consideration, we
insist, is not the gate but the assurance that when
the game is over there will be eleven men who are
fairly sound. in body and not the victims of some
complicated injuries which may cripple them for life.
It's not worth the price.

One more Johns Hopkins man
has attracted widespread praise in
the world and has climbed the ladder of success. This man is Mr.
Henry Lobe Straus, and his most
notable achievement is his invention
of the totalisator, an electrically controlled, automatic, betting device
which recently made its Eastern debut in America at the Pimlico racetrack.
Mr. Straus, a native of Baltimore,
received his Bachelor of Science degree in the School of Engineering
here in 1917, after having graduated from Baltimore City College.
In the scholastic year 1919-20 he
also was an instructor in mechanical
engineering at the Hopkins, and he
is now a successful consulting engineer here in Baltimore.

utilized. The universal approval it
received there led to its introduction
to America, and it got its first
chance at Arlington Park, Chicago,
last summer. Its success there was
instantaneous, and it just recently
was installed at Pimlico. That it
met with the highest approval there
of all concerned is shown by the
fact that Mr. Straus has received a
contract to install his invention at
the Tanforan track in California,
and the machine is now in use at
Hialeah Park in Florida. The universal success of the device is assured, and Mr. Straus is soon to
leave for the West Coast with his
crew of mechanics to install it at
other tracks.

We quote from the Baltimore Evening Sun:

Don Kelly, injured quarterback, showed a real spirit. Before
the game and during the first
half he sat in his street clothes
on the Jay bench. His back was
sore and has been for some time.
He wasn't fit to play football. But
when the teams went to the
dressing rooms at the half, Kelly
also went in. He donned a uniform and asked his coach if he
might play. "I feel fine," he said,
and who could dispute his word.
So Don went in the game, but
his advent didn't help the situation.

The most important problem of
China today is the preservation of
its historic culture, said Father Edward Brennan in an address to the
members of the Charles Carroll
Club at a meeting in Levering Hall,
Sunday.
In his address, Father Brennan asserted that China, whose cultural
antiquity rivals that of the Occidental civilizations, is now at a crisis
in her historical development, as the
great Chinese culture is strongly
threatened by the attitude of the
young people of the nation.
